column2: IPA: [nɐˈxotkə]) is a port city in Primorsky Krai
column4: located on the Trudny Peninsula jutting into the Nakhodka Bay of the Sea of Japan
column5: about 85 kilometers (53 mi) east of Vladivostok

column2: around which the city is organized
column3: was first known to the Russians on the corvette Amerika
column4: which sought shelter in the bay during a storm in 1859. In honor of this occasion
column5: the ice-free and relatively calm bay was named Nakhodka
column6: which in Russian means "discovery" or "lucky find".

column1: An imperial settlement existed here from 1868 to 1872 but was abandoned following the death of its administrator
column2: Harold Furuhjelm. In the fall of 1870
column3: Otto Wilhelm Lindholm established a whaling station across the bay from the settlement. In the spring of 1871 he fitted out his schooner Hannah Rice and sailed to Posyet
column4: where he caught six gray whales.Until the 20th century
column5: the area around the bay remained uninhabited
column6: with the first settlement a small fishing village founded in 1907. When the Soviet government decided to build a harbor in the area in the 1930s
column7: a number of small settlements were founded

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column4: incorporated as Nakhodka City Under Krai Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column5: Nakhodka City Under Krai Jurisdiction is incorporated as Nakhodkinsky Urban Okrug.

column1: Nakhodka has one of the mildest climates in Primorsky Krai and in the whole of the Asian part of Russia thanks to its southerly location and oceanic influences from the Sea of Japan. Average temperature in January is −9.3 °C (15.3 °F); in August (the warmest month)
column2: it is +20.6 °C (69.1 °F). It is classified as a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfb) due to the vast seasonal differences and is a very cold climate for a coastal location below 43 degrees latitude. The maritime influence is manifested in low diurnal temperature variation and a vast summer seasonal lag. Due to the influence of the interior
column3: there is a sharp drop in temperatures between October and November. Half of the year has mean temperatures above 10 °C (50 °F)
column4: in spite of the warmest month being only moderately warm and the coldest month having quite severe cold
column5: with a very low seasonal lag in winter.

column2: based mostly around the port and port-related activity such as fish processing and canning
column3: has suffered since 1991 as Vladivostok was opened to foreign activity again. Local industry also took a hit during the 1998 Russian financial crisis. However
column4: Nakhodka has been declared a free economic zone
column5: and the governments in both Moscow (federal) and Vladivostok (regional) have seemed interested in opening the city further to foreign investment.

column1: Nakhodka is also an important transport junction where goods from Japan are transferred from ships onto the Russian railway system
column2: including the Trans-Siberian Railway portion of the Eurasian Land Bridge.

column1: FC Okean Nakhodka is the only professional sport club in the city. It spent the 1992 and 1993 seasons in the Russian Premier League. It is also the home town of association football player Viktor Fayzulin.
